content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Given my preference for some degree of security and predictability, I would likely choose the strategy that provides me with the most consistent payoff. In this game, choosing B guarantees a smaller but steady income (12$ per round), while choosing R has the potential for a higher payout (45$ if the opponent also chooses R) but also the risk of earning nothing.

Considering there are 75 rounds, it's unlikely that both players will always pick the same option. Even though I could potentially earn more by choosing R in some rounds, the consistency and predictability of earning a minimum amount (12$) with strategy B outweigh the potential risks for me.

So, my choice would be {B}. I acknowledge that there might be instances where I miss an opportunity to gain more, but overall, this approach seems more comfortable given my cautious nature.
